<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8 is: A function parameter should not be modified.
Note that the object referred to by a pointer parameter may be modified, but the pointer itself shall not be modified.
</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of metal_linux_dev_open:
```c
static int metal_linux_dev_open(struct metal_bus *bus,
				const char *dev_name,
				struct metal_device **device)
{
	struct linux_bus *lbus = to_linux_bus(bus);
	struct linux_device *ldev = NULL;
	struct linux_driver *ldrv;
	int error;

	ldev = malloc(sizeof(*ldev));
	if (!ldev)
		return -ENOMEM;

	for_each_linux_driver(lbus, ldrv) {

		/* Check if we have a viable driver. */
		if (!ldrv->sdrv || !ldrv->dev_open)
			continue;

		/* Allocate a linux device if we haven't already. */
		if (!ldev)
			ldev = malloc(sizeof(*ldev));
		if (!ldev)
			return -ENOMEM;

		/* Reset device data. */
		memset(ldev, 0, sizeof(*ldev));
		strncpy(ldev->dev_name, dev_name, sizeof(ldev->dev_name) - 1);
		ldev->fd = -1;
		ldev->ldrv = ldrv;
		ldev->device.bus = bus;

		/* Try and open the device. */
		error = ldrv->dev_open(lbus, ldev);
		if (error) {
			ldrv->dev_close(lbus, ldev);
			continue;
		}

		*device = &ldev->device;
		(*device)->name = ldev->dev_name;

		metal_list_add_tail(&bus->devices, &(*device)->node);
		return 0;
	}

	if (ldev)
		free(ldev);

	return -ENODEV;
}
```
</target_code>

<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
*device = &ldev->device;
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 17.8 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: The statement '*device = &ldev->device;' assigns to the object pointed to by the pointer parameter 'device' (i.e., it sets the caller's struct metal_device *). MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8 permits modifying the object referred to by a pointer parameter but forbids modifying the pointer parameter itself. The code does not alter the parameter 'device' (the pointer value), only the pointee, so there is no violation.
